webTitle: Bringing out the best in your employees doesn't have to be a chore

fields.standfirst: Three businesses tell us about the diverse (and fun) ways in which they maintain high productivity among staff
fields.body:
Creating a happy and productive workforce would be a dream come true for many business owners, but Britain's SMEs are getting better at it. There's a growing realisation among many entrepreneurs that they aren't always the best managers and might need a little help. Higher productivity can be achieved without crushing the morale of employees; some businesses use trainers and mentors, others create intelligent systems, while some opt to build an inspiring workspace. Here, three businesses share their methods:

Techdept

"Young people want to work at Techdept," says founder and CEO Dan Kirby. His online technology agency based at the Electric Works buildings in Sheffield, sounds like every student's dream first job. The office comes with a three-storey helter skelter – the largest in Europe – which takes you from the top floor to the bottom in nine seconds.

"It's one of the coolest offices in the world. It wasn't the cheapest option but it's great, it's inspiring," says Kirby. "We are a creative business and have a team of people who are young and ambitious and they want to come to an environment that has a buzz and is a cool place to be. It's a place which makes you want to up your game."

But Techdept isn't just an office with a slide. Kirby says the business has been thriving since it created the Open Business System (OBS), a method of promoting best practice which aims to "lock down the best methods of doing things while retaining the rights of employees to be able to change things". The business pools its knowledge and experience to create checklists for projects. Staff must follow these, but are free to make alterations if better methods emerge.

"The system is the boss and we all have to follow the system," says Kirby. "When people are in the cut and thrust of getting a website live, it's easy to forget small details. The system helps you through when you're busy. But our manuals admit that we might be wrong – we don't want people to follow blindly."

Because of the OBS, managers no longer have to tell staff what to do. This has freed Kirby and his senior team to follow other projects such as R&D and creating new initiatives. "A lot of management is stuff which is in your head and hasn't been written down."

Caternet

Jerry Brand has been running businesses in the catering sector since the late 1980s. He is currently the managing director of Caternet, which provides an online procurement platform for the food and drinks industry. He says building a strong team is all about communication; allowing all staff to have input and talking to customers to find out what they want.

"We are constantly in touch with our customers. Your average IT business is not developed on service," says Brand. "For me, the key thing is communication. People don't just get out of bed for money. They have to have job satisfaction. If you think about people who don't love their job – can they really be positive about things?"

Encouragingly for cash-strapped growing businesses, Brand believes an open and productive culture is a more effective for retaining staff than pay rises. "You get great staff retention. I can't really remember when the last person left. But we aren't paying over commercial rates, our pay is sensible, but we are pushing the envelope from a technical point of view. A lot of buzzwords fly around, such as continuous improvement and knowledge sharing, but it's what happens."

Brand also recommends giving staff the power to get on with things. His business has a mission statement and he believes leaders need to set out the direction but have faith in the judgment of their staff. "You've got to be a leader and you have got to have confidence in your own leadership. But you've also got to trust them."

Wise Monkey Media

Successful entrepreneurs learn from their strengths and weakness, and many conclude that management and training is not always their strength. Others simply accept that there are professionals who can do a better job and that can help them too. James Neale is the founder of Wise Monkey Media, a creative media and advertising agency in Rock, North Cornwall. His business works with Oxford Innovation (OI), which provides mentoring and training for him and his team.

"You have to admit that sometimes you're not the best person to do the coaching," says Neale. "I think bringing in a coach gives staff a sense of worth. It is a cost but it means they know that they are worth investing in."

The business has six staff but in nearly three years of trading has managed to retain them all. His staff are graduates but the coaching enables them to take on big responsibilities, he says. "My team are being asked to develop their own department. They have skills and specialisms from university, but the mentoring helps them with personal development. They are really good but hearing it from someone else is very helpful. The sessions help them to understand their potential, cope with time management and understand the significance of their work."

Furthermore, he admits he's been on a learning curve since starting-up and recommends mentoring to other entrepreneurs. "I see someone from OI every month to six weeks. It's not a formal discussion. It goes along the lines I take it but at the end of each session I walk away with something I can use to build my business."

Training and mentoring

There are many strong organisations offering training and mentoring for businesses. Here are three popular ones:

Investors in people (IiP)

Investors in People (IiP) is credited by many business owners with having a "transformative effect" on their enterprises. It works with employers to improve structure, employee engagement and focus on development and growth.

Mentorme.co.uk

A gateway site for mentors and business owners looking for help

Manufacturing advisory service (MAS)

MAS provides business support for manufacturing and engineering companies based in England, helping them to improve skill levels and grow.

webTitle: FTSE falters on Ukraine tensions, with Tullow on the slide after another dry well

fields.standfirst: Exploration group fails to find oil and gas at second well in Mauritania
fields.body:
With markets slipping back on growing concerns about the renewed tensions between Russia and Ukraine, it is not a good day to issue a disappointing update.

Tullow Oil has dropped 23p to 838p - the biggest faller in the FTSE 100 - after the explorer and producer said a well off the coast of Mauritania had not found any oil or gas. This is the second failure in the region after it said in February that its first well there had not found oil in commercial quantities.

This second well - Tapendar-1 - will now be plugged and abandoned. Exploration director Angus McCoss said:

The Tapendar-1 exploration well was a bold attempt to open a new oil play in this area of Tullow's highly prospective offshore Mauritania acreage.
Following these opening wells, we and our partners will now pause to analyse the data gathered from the exploration campaign thus far. We will then decide on the location and timings of the next wells which will continue to focus on exploring for conventional oil plays.

Analyst Dragan Trajkov at Oriel Securities said:

The well was targeting net 62m barrels of oil equivalent of prospective resources. [This] would imply no more than 1% impact on the shares this morning. webTitle: William Hill to close 109 shops, blaming hike in betting terminal duty

fields.bodyText: The UK's largest bookmaker, William Hill, is to close 109 shops, blaming the government's surprise hike in betting taxes on high-speed, high-stakes gambling machines. In last month's budget, the chancellor raised duty from 20% to 25% on any machines that can charge more than £5 to play, wiping out a significant portion of revenue from lucrative fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBTs), which account for half of bookmakers' gross profits. William Hill said that if the tax had been applied last year, it would have cost the company £22m. Next year it said about 420 jobs could be lost as a result of the shop closures. The chief executive, Ralph Topping, said: "As a direct result of the government's unexpected announcement about an increase in machine games duty to 25%, we have reviewed shop profitability and will be closing a portfolio of 109 shops this year, putting 420 shop employees at risk of redundancy. In a broadside against the government, Topping said those bearing the brunt of the tax rise would be young workers and female staff – and his company's woes would be replicated across the industry. He told analysts: "We fully expect other companies in the industry to be in a similar position. What's the effect of all that? Well, there's lost revenue to the government. Lost rents and more empty shops on the high street. There's lost jobs. But who loses those jobs? Women, for part-time workers and for 18- to 24-year-olds. 57% of our retail colleagues are women, 30% of them are aged 18 to 24." The rise of the machines, on which punters can bet up to £300 a minute, has been dramatic and controversial. Accused of being highly addictive as well as being linked to crime, the terminals have been in ministers' sights since January, when the prime minister said there were "problems in the betting and gambling industry". In the next fortnight ministers are expected to announce a range of regulatory and planning powers to curb the clustering of shops. However, the industry is addicted to the cash that FOBTs generate. Since 2010, annual player losses have grown from £1.3bn to £1.5bn. In a conference call with analysts, William Hill, which has 2,434 outlets across the UK, admitted that each machine generated £926 a week, up from £904 the year before. There is also concern that betting shops are concentrated in poorer areas – a potential source of social disorder in vulnerable communities. A report in February found that more than £13bn was gambled on high-stakes machines last year by the poorest quarter of England's population. Campaigners against the machines said they doubted whether the closures would be as substantial as the bookmakers claimed. Adrian Parkinson, a spokesman for the Campaign for Fairer Gambling, pointed out that last year William Hill had "opened 120 shops but closed about 70". "In William Hill's 2013 annual report, the company state that they are continuing their strategy of increasing their estate by 1% each year. Indeed, in 2013 they ended up with 59 more shops than they started with. That was about a 2% increase in their shop estate. So it remains to be seen whether these proposed shop closures are negated by new shop openings and whether any of these closures will be compensated by relocations." Parkinson said that just two operators – Ladbrokes and William Hill – now own 52% of all UK betting shops – up from 48% just four years ago. Expansions such as this are often followed at some point by a reassessment of the whole estate, just as Ladbrokes, which has grown by 10% compared with William Hill's 5% growth over this period, has done. Shares in William Hill and Ladbrokes fell sharply last month. Ladbrokes has also said it will close shops. However, William Hill reported a further leap in the revenues from its betting websites, with stakes laid online by punters up 39% year on year. Gambling on mobile devices was up by 78%. But it said operating profits had fallen by 14%, which it partly attributed to two weeks out of 13 in the quarter when customers laid successful bets. Analysts said that the closure of stores would not affect William Hill's prospects unduly. Simon Gergel, at Allianz Global Investors, said: "Overall we think William Hill is well positioned for the future of the UK and international betting industry, which is being driven increasingly by online betting."
